name: WSJ
text:
Medaria Arradondo moved quickly to reform policing tactics when he became police chief of Minneapolis. In today's episode of The Journal podcast, @djfroschWSJ explains why it's easier to change the policies of a police force than its culture.

name: WSJ
text: The New York City Police Department opened an investigation into officers who accelerated their police cars into protesters blocking their way, Mayor Bill de Blasio said https://t.co/Asvq7AIhMZ

name: WSJ
text: Israeli Defense Minister Benny Gantz orders military to bolster security as the country prepares to begin annexing parts of occupied West Bank as early as next month https://t.co/77J7H3Q5lY

name: WSJ
text: Up until a few years ago, chief executives and big businesses tended to steer away from hot-button issues. Now, many leaders of industry say more consumers and employees expect brands and businesses to have a point of viewâ€”and share it. https://t.co/o0wYbkIgv0

name: WSJ
text: The Census Bureau said it reached its target to get at least 60.5% of households to respond to the 2020 census, despite disruptions created by the Covid-19 pandemic https://t.co/HFBrF6Csdu

name: WSJ
text: The U.S. economy could take the better part of a decade to fully recover from the coronavirus pandemic and related shutdowns, a U.S. budget agency said https://t.co/hvhmDELcA1

name: WSJ
text: Reports of run-ins with protesters or police have come from media outlets of all types, from national TV channels such as CNN and Fox News to newspapers and local news operations https://t.co/YGjWSXFeVX

name: WSJ
text: From @WSJopinion: The bias is real. But like Nixon against the broadcast networks, Trump goes too far in his attack on social-media platforms, writes @BoulderPreston. https://t.co/lCt2vXagt1

name: WSJ
text: Musicians and entertainment executives are encouraging workers to take Tuesday as a chance to reflect on racism in the country, in some cases even if that means taking off work https://t.co/bTYvDGslce

name: WSJ
text: Two Brooklyn lawyers and a woman from upstate New York were arraigned on federal charges after allegedly participating in separate Molotov cocktail attacks on police cars in New York City https://t.co/aVSjzeJr4z

name: WSJ
text: A federal survey found that about 26,000 deaths in U.S. nursing homes were tied to Covid-19, a total that likely falls short of showing the full toll https://t.co/IkFIcpORku

name: WSJ
text: The Taliban share a close relationship with al Qaeda and continues to provide a haven for its members, a United Nations report says https://t.co/O8tkS1RcCQ

name: WSJ
text: The 67,000 National Guard members now on the streets for the protests and Covid-19 represent the largest number ever activated in the U.S. https://t.co/guRCNGjg4P

name: WSJ
text: By late morning Tuesday Hong Kong time, the cityâ€™s Hang Seng Index and stock benchmarks in Japan and South Korea had all risen 0.5% to 1.2% https://t.co/sLbk5Wbk7u

name: WSJ
text: Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/xn8L40OWju https://t.co/IbkqZV5mp9

name: WSJ
text: Most of the layoffs at personal-shopping service and clothing retailer Stitch Fix will take place in September, and those affected will have the opportunity to relocate https://t.co/KWM8zB4QGv

name: WSJ
text: New York lawmakers will convene next week to overhaul a law that keeps police disciplinary records hidden from public view https://t.co/jeIIAaDsph

name: WSJ
text: A retired University of Miami professor who wrote a book on organized crime laundered over $2 million in proceeds from a bribery scheme in Venezuela, according to prosecutors https://t.co/IctDfatKjF

name: WSJ
text: From @WSJopinion: U.S. education was failing students well before Covid-19, and online lectures arenâ€™t the answer. The future is in personalized, interactive online courses, augmented by teacher-coaches, writes @andykessler. https://t.co/OKSFpamUBq
